content.intro: You have an idea. You've validated it with a few potential users. Now you need to build it — fast, lean, and without burning your entire budget. That's exactly what an MVP is for. But here's the problem most founders face: they don't know where to start, how much it'll cost, or how to choose the right development partner. In this guide, we break down everything you need to know about working with an MVP development company — from real cost numbers to the exact tech stack we recommend at Kunamix.

sections.heading: What Is an MVP and Why Does It Matter for Your Startup?
sections.body:
An MVP — Minimum Viable Product — is the simplest version of your product that solves one core problem for your target user. It's not a half-baked product. It's a strategic first version designed to validate your idea with real users before you invest heavily in full development.

Here's why it matters:

Most startups fail not because of bad ideas — but because they build too much, too soon. They spend 12 months and $30,000+ building a product that nobody wants. An MVP forces you to answer the most important question first: Will people actually use this?

With a well-built MVP, you can launch in 6–8 weeks, get real user feedback, attract early investors, and iterate based on data — not assumptions. That's the difference between a startup that survives and one that burns out before finding product-market fit.

sections.heading: Real MVP Development Cost: An Honest Breakdown
sections.body:
One of the biggest advantages of working with Kunamix is cost-efficiency without compromising quality. Here's a realistic cost breakdown based on MVP type:

**Simple Web App MVP (e.g., SaaS dashboard, booking platform)**
- Timeline: 4–6 weeks
- Cost: $1,800 – $5,000 (₹1.5L – ₹4L)
- Includes: UI/UX design, frontend, backend API, database, basic auth

**Mobile App MVP (Android or iOS)**
- Timeline: 6–10 weeks
- Cost: $3,500 – $10,000 (₹3L – ₹8L)
- Includes: React Native/Flutter app, REST API backend, push notifications, admin panel

**Full-Stack Product MVP (Web + Mobile + Admin)**
- Timeline: 8–14 weeks
- Cost: $7,000 – $18,000 (₹6L – ₹15L)
- Includes: Everything above + cloud deployment, analytics, CMS

**What affects the cost?**
The number of features you insist on including in v1 is the #1 cost driver. Every feature you defer to v2 saves you 20–30% in development time and cost. A good MVP development partner will push back on feature creep — that's a sign they respect your budget.

At Kunamix, we always start with a feature prioritization session before writing a single line of code. It saves our clients an average of $1,500–$2,500 in unnecessary early development.

sections.heading: The Best Tech Stack for Your MVP in 2026
sections.body:
Choosing the wrong tech stack is one of the most expensive mistakes a startup can make. Rebuilding your entire backend at scale because your original stack couldn't handle growth is a nightmare — and it happens more than you think.

Here's what we recommend at Kunamix for most MVP builds in 2026:

**Frontend: Next.js (React)**
Why: Fast, SEO-friendly, supports both static and dynamic pages, massive ecosystem. Perfect for web-based MVPs.

**Backend: Node.js + Express**
Why: JavaScript across the stack means faster development, easy to find developers, handles real-time features well.

**Database: PostgreSQL**
Why: Reliable, scalable, supports complex queries. Better than MongoDB for most structured data use cases.

**Mobile: React Native or Flutter**
Why: One codebase for Android and iOS. React Native if your web team uses React. Flutter if you need the best native-like performance.

**ORM: Prisma**
Why: Clean, type-safe database access. Reduces bugs significantly.

**Hosting: Vercel (frontend) + AWS or Railway (backend)**
Why: Vercel deployments are instant. AWS gives you room to scale without migrating later.

This stack is what powers most modern SaaS products globally. It's battle-tested, has strong community support, and will comfortably scale from 0 to 100,000 users without a full rewrite.

sections.heading: How to Choose the Right MVP Development Company
sections.body:
There are thousands of dev shops globally. Most will take your money and deliver average results. Here's how to separate the good from the rest:

**1. Check their actual code, not just their portfolio website**
Ask for a GitHub link or code sample. Any serious dev company should have public repos or be willing to share sanitized code samples. This tells you more than any case study.

**2. Do they have UI/UX capability in-house?**
Many dev companies outsource design — which creates communication gaps and delays. Your MVP needs design and development working together from day one.

**3. How do they handle feature scope?**
If a company just says 'yes' to everything you ask for — run. A good technical partner will challenge your feature list and help you cut it down to what truly matters for v1.

**4. What does their communication look like?**
You should get weekly progress updates, access to a staging environment, and a clear Git workflow. If they can't explain their process clearly, their code will reflect that.

**5. Do they offer post-launch support?**
Launching is not the finish line. Bugs happen. Users find edge cases. Make sure your partner offers at least 30–60 days of post-launch support.

At Kunamix, we include all of the above as standard — not as an upsell.

content.intro: You started your business with a vision. But somewhere between managing suppliers, tracking inventory, handling invoices, and following up with customers — you ended up managing spreadsheets instead of growth. Most small and medium businesses lose 15–30% of their operational efficiency to manual processes, data silos, and disconnected tools. The fix isn't hiring more people. It's smarter software. In this guide, we'll break down why custom ERP software is no longer a luxury for large enterprises — it's a growth lever for SMBs — and how you can have one built specifically for your business without burning your budget.

sections.heading: What Is ERP Software — And Why Off-the-Shelf Tools Aren't Enough
sections.body:
ERP stands for Enterprise Resource Planning. In simple terms, it's a single system that connects every part of your business: sales, inventory, HR, accounts, production, and customer management — all in one place.

But here's the problem with tools like Tally, Zoho, or SAP for SMBs:

- They're built for a generic business — not yours
- You end up paying for features you'll never use
- Customisation is expensive, slow, and often impossible
- Data still lives in multiple places — killing efficiency
- You depend on their update schedules, pricing, and uptime

What growing businesses actually need is a system that works exactly the way their operations work — not the other way around.

sections.heading: 5 Signs Your Business Desperately Needs Custom Software
sections.body:
If any of the following sound like your day-to-day reality, you're already losing money to manual processes.

**1. Your team lives in Excel sheets**
If your operations manager tracks inventory in a spreadsheet, your accountant reconciles data in another sheet, and your sales team manages leads in a third — your business is running on guesswork. One wrong formula, one deleted row, one outdated file — and you're flying blind.

**2. You can't see your business clearly in real time**
When a business owner can't answer 'What's our stock level right now?' or 'Which customers haven't paid in 30 days?' without calling three people — that's a data problem. And data problems cost money, always.

**3. You're manually doing things that should be automatic**
Sending payment reminders manually. Updating purchase orders by hand. Generating invoices one by one. If your team spends hours per week on tasks a system could do in seconds, your labour cost is being wasted on low-value work.

**4. You can't scale without chaos**
Your current process works for your current volume. But what happens when you double your orders, add a new location, or onboard 10 more staff? If the honest answer is 'it breaks down' — you need a system that scales with you.

**5. You've outgrown your current software**
You started with a basic tool when the business was small. Now it's becoming a bottleneck. Limitations in reporting, user access, integrations, or workflows are slowing your team down every single day.

sections.heading: What Custom ERP Software Actually Does for Your Business
sections.body:
A well-built custom ERP replaces the patchwork of tools and manual processes with a unified, intelligent system. Here's what that looks like in practice:

- Inventory management — real-time tracking, low-stock alerts, purchase order automation
- Sales & CRM — pipeline visibility, follow-up reminders, customer history
- Accounts & billing — automated invoicing, payment tracking, tax-ready reporting
- HR & attendance — payroll automation, leave management, role-based access
- Production or service tracking — job cards, task assignment, milestone reporting
- Dashboard & analytics — live business metrics so you make decisions on data, not instinct

The result: Your team stops firefighting and starts executing. You stop guessing and start growing.

sections.heading: Why SMBs Are Choosing Custom Development Over SaaS Subscriptions
sections.body:
The subscription SaaS model sounds great — until you do the math.

A mid-sized business paying $200–$500/month on SaaS tools (CRM, ERP, payroll, invoicing, etc.) spends $2,400–$6,000 per year — on tools that still don't fully fit their workflow.

A custom ERP built by Kunamix typically costs a one-time investment of $3,000–$10,000 depending on complexity. You own it. You control it. You can modify it as your business evolves.

**SaaS vs Custom ERP — The Real Comparison:**

- Ownership: SaaS = rented tool | Custom = your asset
- Customisation: SaaS = limited | Custom = built for your exact workflow
- Cost over 3 years: SaaS subscriptions often cost MORE than a custom build
- Data control: SaaS = stored on their servers | Custom = your infrastructure
- Scalability: SaaS = their roadmap | Custom = your priorities
